Two people I know have passed this week. One was murdered. I can't stand being awake right now. I can't get even a single text back from a person who was my best friend a month ago, a person who I've given so much for. I worry I'll never hear from her again. And my head and heart can't stop worrying that I may have already seen Rowan for the last time. I'm trying to be patient, trying to pray, take deep breaths, keep hoping. But this week has been brutal, and keeps taking. And I've never loved anything as much as I love witnessing that boy just exist near me. Please, God, please anyone that's listening: don't let me lose him. I've lost and given up pleanty in my life, but I honestly don't know if I could handle that. It might be my final straw. He's what makes everything else bearable and even beautiful. Please, God, please.

Went on a date last night. Hard to matter. She's my best friend and the thing that makes me feel the most everything. I get that we'll never be married and she'll never be in love with me. I just miss her. Miss her and her missing me. Do you know how horrible it feels when someone stops missing you, stops worrying about you? Not just stops being in love with you, but stops actively loving you at all? No texts to send me good thoughts or feelings. No (even short) calls to make sure I'm doing okay, or that I'm not losing my shit. No making plans or even any interaction unless I initiate it or she needs something. No missing me No missing me No missing me Like I miss my best friend Six years or more, and she'll still drop me and close the door hard for the first romantic notion or pretty face. For anything really. I've always been the default, the backup plan, the thing she reactivates when she's bored or doesn't have anything else terribly interesting going on. I've given up so many parts of myself, of my pride, of my self-security, of my self-esteem just trying to make her see me as special, unique, important to 1/10th of the degree I see her that way. Not be in love with me, just love me. All I ever see is her walking away. And she gets to do this to me forever. I'll always let her back in. Always want her to be okay. Always leave any event, date, whatever to come pick her up if she needs me, to talk to her. When I know she's bad, I text, I call, I check on her. I try to surprise her with nice things. It's never the same in reverse. She has so much regard for every other friend besides me. And that is the part that hurts like a bitch. Not what she does, but that it's not hard for her. Not that she leaves, but that it's so easy. Not that I miss her, but that she doesn't miss me beyond a passing thought. That I need her in my life in some way, shape, or form, and I honestly doubt she would have much of a reaction at all if she was never going to see me again. At the very least, I expected a "Happy Father's Day".

I think he just figured out the best and easiest way to make you a puppet on his strings. He knew that the best way to keep you was to deny you what you want. What you have such an easy time getting. It can be quietly and subtly held over you, making you curious question why why why? So you try all the sarcastic smiles and go extra miles to make him happy, to hold some hope. Just like he knows you will. And if he ever decides to give you what you want, whether its a relationship or the body you claim you haven't had, you'll be grateful. Even if he holds it from you after that. Heck, knowing how puppeteers love to play it'd be too easy to just give you what you want once, and then shy away. Or go away. So you build it as some holy temple of a moment in your mind and wish blind to do or be anything that let's you go there again. How wise he was to see which strings you need, that you only want what you can't have and the wondering why.

I dreamt I went on a trip into the deep woods with my father. Someplace green. Someplace warm. Probably south. Maybe Virginia, Missippi, Alabama. Dirt paths every direction. You had to go long, tight roads to get anywhere, and miles past miles to arrive in even tiny, half-broken, should-have-been-torn-down gas stations. I don't know how long we were there or why we were staying, but at some point I fixated on part of the community. There was this ancient and holy sized victorian-colonial moss covered plantation homes housing a religious commune of extreme proportions, all south-style pilgrims. Menonite and cult-eyed men and women straight plane white dress shirts, black dress pants, everyone different but completely the same. Poison oak trees littered the lawns, and the building itself was mammoth, dark doors like mouths that ate everyone who went in with complete shadow. Smaller homes grew like weeds on the outstretches of the properties, extending the hold of the ground's seed. A sunny disposition that appeared, to me, to hide some visceral secret. 
Against my father's approval(he just along for the vacation), my curiosity fixated. I kept finding ways to prod or put myself in position near these people. Opened doors that should have been locked, talking to the more open or too-friendly of that hilltop parish. I was caught red-handed a few times and told blankly that I shouldn't be here, this was private property, I should leave. 

One night, aching for answers, I assumed dress similar to the congregation therein and snuck myself inside, eyes down and unnoticed. I passed deep within the house and found myself falling down a rabbit hole of mesmeric design. I found rope-pulley elevators and spiral staircases that led down, down, down into deep and placid darkness. I walked past endless rooms, some closed, others open and candle-lit that I quickly made my way past--echoing coughs, a babe crying, insipid whisperings, and symbols scrawled on the dirt of hollow hallway walls. I knew I'd found something sprawling the limits of the land above, linking all the outcropping houses and well beyond. Forgone decades or centuries had built this place. My heart began to race in my ears, and something pulled me to stay but an absolute fear compelled me to leave before I was caught and...dealt with. I made my way to the closest rope-rung ladder and climbed up past outreaching root and ancient time. 

The wooden barrier at the top gave after several strong thrusts, and I broke into daylight in haze of dust motes. Coughing, I lifted myself into a broken-light shack and pulled the door open. I was well behind the House at this point, and picked a loose direction to get out of there. As I walked, I tried to ignore what I had begun to see from the corners of my eye--hidden in the bushes and tall grass, those same unexcitable men held machine guns trained beads on me and following each step. Eventually there was no more pretending I hadn't seen them, not that it was a pretense they were attempting very hard to keep. Hands up, eyes looking up to stars, I panicked thinking this might be the end. But a row of candlelight congregation dressed in white came like some sinuous glowing snake and aligned themselves into the grass carved amphitheater some place behind the home. All sat, and waited. A man came towards me, the reverend. His half-lit visage and deep jowls bespoke Billy Tuttle. He sat down beside me and asked me why, why had it come to this, why couldn't I have kept well enough alone. All I could think to answer was the truth, that a mad desire had affixed me to find answers--promises poured from me to never speak of anything I had seen, and of my utter compulsion to return, to stay, if for nothing beyond answers to what this venerable place had been. And he told me I was treading sacred ground, Carcosa--images broke into my mind of a truth older than the time's turning wheel. A thousand-mile wide basin of dirt and life and water, a white female wolf god I saw cryinghowling at a moon older than the earths and larger than our solar system, and she screamed and fought(but almost beckoned) as four black he-wolf creators fell upon her in a rage, mouths and jaws locking on her and ripping her to the pieces that would become all sentience, and the blood that flowed made all things. I could not understand. I could not. The conception shook me and held me even more abstrusely to that place of origin.

He asked me to stay, and I hesitated for the life I'd left behind me, the things unfinished, goodbyes unsaid. I begged to be allowed to return, and he laid out a way to regain entrance--a sign to look for within a range of a certain body of land, one that would promise I had found what I was looking for. But when he spoke his voice was the sound of a thousand winds, a hundred-thousand pages being torn away at once, and finally, "Take off your mask, now you must go" 

And I awoke. Feeling the sweat and faith of a dream unlike any I'd ever had.

Maybe you're too busy. Or maybe you're wiser than I and know exactly how easily we could mess things up if you said or did too much. I like to think that. Like to hope that. Instead of thinking maybe those things are just me too. That maybe you don't even notice that much. Or that you're too happy to conceive of even taking too many chances. Or maybe you just...have nothing to say. Maybe you aren't filled to bursting with loving, missing, beautiful things about me. You never write my beauty or tiny pieces you miss out. Never structure poetry around my jawline or sad eyes. Maybe, if not in base feeling, we're just divided on intensity. Maybe I don't still make that same fire bloom in your belly and ache in your chest like you do me. I'm always feeling like something integral is missing, maybe you missed it. Maybe an army of lovers has made me a distant memory for you. Maybe the waves of girls, all delicate beautiful intense, has washed away the recollection of our book of endless pages. He will never write her poems that describe the perfect rhythm that her heart beats against her ribcage when you lay your head to her chest. The criss-cross shapes her fingers make, how her hands are forever showing signs of what she's been interested in lately, spelling stories in bits of ink, broken polish, grease, dirt or chocolate. He will never read her stories till she has to fall asleep, and if he does they won't bear the same bold voices and tricky pronunciation, the same love of reading. He will never understand her like I did: wholly and completely. I never understood her. But I knew that I couldn't. Like trying to drink the ocean or hold a river in place. Like trying to understand a tempest, like ascribing reason to the forces of time or space. Or fate. That girl always felt like a hectare of heartache. Trying to figure it out was pointless, you just enjoy the ride, the repeating hundred-thousand foot rise and fall, quick or slow. And you try, you try, to survive. He will never play the guitar and sing her tired songs of love and loss until his fingers ache, never miss her 7 kinds of laughter or do stupid self-deprecating things just to watch her giggle, or give her an opening for a joke. He will never tell lame and stupid puns while she rolls her eyes and stifles weak laughs. Never do genius word play in rote back and forth. Never breathe language in the syncopating rhythm and beautiful syntax of prose and poetry. Laugh at grammar jokes, be torn over postsecrets. They will never smoke, smoke, smoke the night away, hating the poison and sharing every last one until both packs run out. He will never last. Like a hundred stubs and butts, he will be put out. He will never yearn for or appreciate a good writing pen for the joy of scribbling out a bit of poetry or notating a book. Will never wade in baths with her with nothing but humor and fun in mind. Honestly, I'm tired of making lists and she can fill in the rest of the infinite blanks. She knows them just as well as me. He may be amazing, kind, just what she needs right now. But he will never be me. For all our chaos, we made a kind of sense that is very truly rare in this existence. Boon companions, kindred spirits, best friends who just couldn't keep our hands off each other. He will never fuck her like I did. They will never ever achieve that level of comfort and chemistry. We fucked like dying stars. Easily my best. They will never fuck with same passion and total loss of material existence, able to be held and alive in a place that's pure passion. Will never tease and degrade her in the heat of the moment. And if he can ever stomach the attempt it will be faux, not enough, no intensity. Like a bad actor running lines. He may share kisses and fucks with her, but it will never share the ecstatic release and rekindled desire that we pushed like magic through the pores of our skin. It will never be temptation, sin, the embracing destruction of a relit fire. They may have fights and make-ups but never in the emphatic bliss and beauty, never in the same absolute intensity. They may miss each other and smile at reunion, but never in those surreal movie-like moments of joy and realness. They may cry together, but not in the weeping collapsing mess of broken clutching each other for absolute safety. Their fights, hate, love and friendship can never be ours. Nothing else ever could. Destruct and rebirth phoenix love each other sick and hopeless. The innumerable ways we lay. The break and release, tips of fingers moving hair gently away from crying sad and beautiful eyes, seeing into each other's soul for tiny inescapable moments. The tender forgetting every bad thing just to be beside each other a few minutes longer, just to remember. He will never love our son, your son, like I did. Never marvel at not just his perfection, but all the subtle and beautiful mesmerizing ways he mimics his mother. Breathes her same cells, carries a part of her inside his tiny, wonderful little chest. Never want to die a hundred thousand times over before losing or hurting our little billowing irish tree. Our little viking superhero. He may hold him, but he will never cradle him with the same care and constant awe. Never want to bawl his eyes out just watching our son sleep so angelic and mystifying. He will never hold your hand tight through the pangs of pregnancy. Be by your side through each discovering step. I have. You will be able to say that about very very few people in your life. You're a song playing so loud in my ears. You're a taste or vision I can't escape. My every touch misses you.I hate still wanting you after everything. I hate that I feel sickly heroin-addicted to your sex, that I crave tangling sheets with you again. Not just emotionally, not even for the most part. I hate not moving forward. Hate wishing I could stare into your eyes. Or just just just JUST kiss you one more time, just one more goddamned time. Just to have that magic one more fucking minute. It would be like wandering the desert, mouth packed full of salt, and finding a familiar well. An endless drink, quenching every ache. I can't imagine not kissing you again the rest of my life. Like never touching water again, never feeling the warmth of the sun on my skin ever again. Like no more tagalongs or never running my hands over guitar strings. Like losing my ears and never again hearing music, or my eyes burning out so I could never read another word. I hate how I feel just thinking about it. But mostly I hate being a poet with a poet's heart, one that never learns to forever let go, to find beauty in the future enough to stop romanticizing the past. Our beautiful, blessed past. We have a shared history that intertwines like branches grown to ropes. Like the tattoos on our forearms we are, in ways, inseparable.

He also cheated on her six times during their relationship. Each time he promised he'd spend the rest of his life making it up to her, digressed how weak he was, how selfish. She forgave him, and loved him. After all, they were each other's, and they promised to always be so in that little white church down home. The little white church on the weedy outskirts of town where her mama'd been married so many years before. And things went on for a time.... 
He didn't beat her often, and never very seriously. And fewer times still did he ever get angry enough to leave truly visible bruises. The make-up covering most of it, the shame buried in coats of concealer or shades of eye-shadow. She blamed herself mostly. He cared, he loved her, and she knew that--she just...had a way of making him so upset. She should know how he got when he was upset, how out of control he became. Frightening, out of control. She pressed her feelings to loving page each night, folding the corners of each leaf of paper to weigh down the emotions she buried deep inside herself. A monstrous picture of perfect self-control. 
She'd met him still young and alive, in the summer of 1941, a strikingly different life than this disheveled and reticent place they'd created for themselves. The red-scare of communism had run rampant, fear-mongering ate the country alive, and the witch-hunters pyres burned brighter than the lights of all those big cities. But while the seeds of distrust sprang up between neighbors, brother turning on brother, John and her seemed to make sense. "John and Sue" became an almost immediate title to friends and family, no longer needing singular monikers, postulating instead purely in the collected parenthetical. The nights and the days melded into one rush of ecstatic creation, ripping a hole in the wide-world fit to make God turn a quick eye. The love between them was a force akin to dying stars by which they were both consumed alive. In a nation frightened to turn a corner without pointing a finger, they'd found a secret space of a love, a trust, a pinpoint for truth. Or so it'd felt. But later, when the world begun to grow, to become a metaforest for the digital age of convenience, access, comfort...well, then, then they'd had no room for any kind of belief. It was too late then. Imagine the confusion when her Always Sun and Forever Warmth became the cold winds of night, all light fleeing the relationship with her. As kisses became shackles, and nights alone with him a nightmare, she could only ever blame one thing. One tiny grain of sand had come along and knocked down the Taj Mahal; one mistake in the pre-programming of predisposition: the drink. The rot-gut whiskey he'd take to chucking back with the boys from the steel-mill at that hole-in-the-wall shit-joint of theirs every night when he got off work, and routinely when he wasn't working too. Oh, he'd drank wine most of his life in casual circumstances, of course; parties, the dinner table, the occasional special moments by themselves. She'd frankly always been flummoxed that he so rarely lost his head or said too many free words among friends. Her in full-blush staring at him in dead-wonder at how he always so precisely limited his drinking to never effect him. When she finally worked her tongue up to ask him about it he simply, and uneloquently stated, "My pa always had too strong a taste. He seemed to see hell and breathe it too. That ain't for me." Maybe if they hadn't lost the house, that great big stupid house full of all the things they bought instead of speaking. Maybe if they hadn't lost that dumb damn hunk of wood and paint, maybe then he would have never turned to working the steel mill, would never have taken up with Shaila Rogers, Tim Rosby or the rest of that sorry gang of wild-men. Living day to day, never caring hell for what storms they brought in raging clouds to the lives of others. 
But it was too late for all that thought now. Time had passed too quickly for the best bits, and too slowly for the worst. Slower and slower it had seemed before something in John finally just gave up, spiraled out, broke down. He'd just pulled one of his longer disappearing acts at a whole 13 days missing without a word. He'd unlocked the door late, dragging mud on the carpet. He'd come to bed after only having stepped to the basement for a moment, and held her close to him as she slept. The next morning she'd found scraps of his clothing in the stove, and had never asked about it after--losing the memory to time for some long years. He seemed to walk through life in a haze, distant and unfazed. He began to drink less and stay home with her more often, reading in the bed until late into the night. Shortly after he'd quit the steel mill and got on at a small grocery. When his friends dried up, she ached to let him know how important he was without them. He smiled at her jokes, and surprised her more often, but he never lost that hollow look in his eyes. Somewhere deep down in his pupils you could see the raw ache. That never stopped.
She still clung to the memory of their first anniversary. The flowers. That silly boquet she remembered to this day clear as a bell, and remembering her thinking 'Him down on one knee with such a smile and that tattered ink-stained old hat off his head and catching her breath in great gasps the ring the ring the ring oh my god won't molly platt be jealous and yes yes, of course, yes!' Yes, she treasured the flowers. There every year, without fail, through the best and the worst times. Through their salvation, damnation, and eventual bit of dull redemption. There were always the flowers.
